urn:contentItem:5CRR-5FN1-F03R-N224-00000-00Title II is the only path to net neutrality. Here's why almost nobody thinks the FCC will take it2014-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:37:22ZLexisNexisTitle II is the only path to net neutrality. Here's why almost nobody thinks the FCC will take itJeff John Roberts

Jul 24, 2014 (Gigaom:http://www.gigaom.com Delivered by Newstex)
'Speak softly and carry a big stick,' is good advice, but it only works if you use the stick to smash someone in the mouth from time to time. If people think your stick is just decoration, you lose power.
This is the FCC's dilemma as it tries to design rules to prevent broadband providers from playing favorites when they deliver web traffic. It has a big stick, called 'Title II,' but most people think the agency lacks the political juice to wield it against some very powerful companies.


And while some have proposed 'light touch' options to avoid a confrontation, that may be wishful thinking: FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler will have to go all-in and swing the Title II stick, or just it lay down altogether. To get a better idea of Wheeler's predicament, here's a fresh look at Title II: what it is, who is for and against it, and why insiders think Wheeler won't use his only weapon to enforce net neutrality.
Title II: what it means in plain English
The telecom scene is jargon-heavy, and the Title II debate is no exception: the crux of the fight turns on whether the FCC should re-classify broadband companies as a 'telecommunications service' instead of as an 'information service.'
Why does the label matter? In theory, it should not: the FCC could call Comcast a cat food company, and it would still provide the same services. But under FCC rules, the 'telecommunications service' label is important because it triggers a series of obligations[1] under Title II of the Communications Act of 1934.

Those obligations, which cover everything from price-caps to closed-captioning to emergency services, have traditionally applied to 'common carriers' like wireline phone companies, and place restrictions on how they run their business. That's why broadband providers like Comcast and Verizon don't want to live under Title II — they want to continue on as 'information services' under a different part of the law (Title I) which, on paper, involves a lighter regulatory load.
There's one more important element to the Title II debate, however. It's the idea of 'forbearance,' which is industry-speak for the FCC's power to impose some obligations but not others. For instance, the agency could say the rules of section 224[2] on 'Pole Attachments' no longer apply, while leaving other sections in place — perhaps section 202[3] (non-discrimination) and section 208[4] (complaint procedures).
This would mean that Title II would not be as onerous as it appears, but it would still require a legal two-step on the part of the FCC: the agency would have to issue a re-classification order to make the broadband companies a 'telecommunications service' under Title II, and then declare a series of forbearance measures to explain which parts of the law will not apply.
The FCC, by the way, has the legal authority to do all this. There's no doubt about it, because the D.C. Court of Appeals said so in a thunderbolt court ruling[5] in January. The ruling struck down the FCC's last set of rules on net neutrality, but said they would have been legal if they had been issued under Title II.
Why some say we need Title II, and others say we can't have it
The Electronic Frontier Foundation recently took the position[6] that the FCC should use its Title II power to bring broadband providers to heel. This declaration, coming from a group that has long been suspicious of government regulating the internet, came as a surprise and reflects growing concerns over the power of Comcast and other big ISP's.
According to the EFF, Title II is necessary to stop a future where big ISP's can give special 'fast lane' treatment to websites they like (or that pay them) and slow down small sites, or ones tied to their competitors. Comcast, for instance, might one day decide to give a speed boost to its tech site Re/Code, while slowing down readers' access to Gigaom.
The EFF isn't the only one calling for Title II. The CEO of Kickstarter recently warned[7] that 'fast lanes' could impede the next generation of web services from emerging because a future Facebook or Twitter might not be able to afford the toll to reach customers in the first place. The Title II chorus is also coming from the likes of Reddit and Netflix, and from politicians like Sen. Charles Schumer[8] (D-NY).

The goal of the Title II advocates is not, of course, to reclassify broadband providers for the heck of it. Rather, they believe the FCC has no other choice if it truly wants to prevents ISPs from favoring some websites over others. As Netflix told[9] the agency last week, two previous attempts to use other laws to enforce net neutrality have failed — meaning it's Title II or bust.
Meanwhile, big telecom companies have come down just as strongly against Title II. Their best argument is that reclassification would turn them into public utilities with no incentive to invest in pipes or new technologies. Comcast said so in a recent blog post[10], adding that Title II is not necessary given the FCC's auxiliary power under Title I, and trying to use it will only cause a mess of legal headaches.
The anti-Title II companies, which also include Verizon and ATT, are supported by some conservatives[11] who take the position that the FCC will stifle innovation, and by Republican politicians like Rep. Bob Latta (R-Oh) who is trying to pass a law[12] to clip the FCC's net neutrality wings.
As you can see, the Title II debate is divisive, which has led some to call for a middle ground — one that is unlikely to work.
'Title II lite' is an illusion
Net neutrality advocates who want to help the FCC escape its dilemma have come forward with ideas that, they suggest, will let the agency impose Title II but without too much screeching from Comcast and the gang.
One idea comes via the Mozilla Foundation[13], which has called for the FCC to apply Title II but only at a deeper layer of the internet where ISP's meet 'edge providers' like Level 3 or Netflix. Another comes from law professor Tim Wu, an authority in the field who first coined the term 'net neutrality, and who proposes[14] a belt-and-suspenders approach:
the Commission's best course is to pass tough rules under 706 with Title II as the backup, to insure the rules survive a court challenge. This strategy may actually ward off court challenges, given that it presents the carriers with a kind of trip wire.
Under Wu's proposal, the FCC would draw, but not fire, its Title II weapon, while also keeping the ISP's in line on a day-to-day basis with the Title I powers it has used in the past.
These proposals hold out the promise of Title II lite — a way to show the ISPs that the FCC means business but without triggering a political brawl. And the FCC appears to be listening:
.@rgslutsky[15] We specifically asked questions about the Wu/Tejas/Mozilla "sender-side" #netneutrality[16] idea in our request 4 comments, so very.— Gigi Sohn (@GigiBSohnFCC) July 14, 2014[17]
The problem, however, is that opponents will likely fight just as fiercely no matter how Title II is invoked, since it is not the details they oppose so much as any type of reclassification in the first place.
According to Paul Werner[18], a veteran telecom lawyer at Shepherd Mullin, Wu is correct that agencies like the FCC can and do create rules under multiple sources of law; however, in the case of Title II, Werner suggested by email that Wu's 'backup' plan wouldn't fly with the courts:
But what the courts have said the FCC cannot do is use Title II as a 'backstop' for imposing core Title II obligations - such as non-discrimination or common carriage requirements - on internet service providers. The DC Circuit invalidated just such an approach recently in holding that the FCC cannot backdoor Title II regulations under the guise of its Section 706 authority. Instead, the fundamental legal and policy choice facing the Commission is whether or not to re-classify internet service as a 'telecommunications service' subject to the full complement of Title II regulations.
This is another way of saying that, when it comes to Title II, the FCC can't be half-pregnant. While the agency could invoke Title II and immediately forebear on its more onerous obligations, it would still have to stand and fight for Title II in the first place — and that is something it's reluctant to do.
Why the FCC won't use its only weapon
The FCC has received more than a million public comments about net neutrality — a huge response, second only to Janet Jackson's infamous nipple-slip — and many of them explicitly call for Title II. But, for now, those comments won't matter too much. Title II may have popular support and it appears to be the correct policy choice, but that's still no match for corporate realpolitik.
Simply put, Title II advocates just don't have the money and lobbying firepower to challenge the telecom industry. New figures[19], for instance, showed that ISPs have spent $42.4 million so far this year, and that Comcast alone spent nearly $4.5 million in the second quarter.
The notion that ISPs are throwing money around is nothing new, of course, but the critical issue when it comes to Title II is that no one is spending on the other side.

FCC Commissioners (L to R): Commissioner Ajit Pai, Commissioner Mignon Clyburn, Chairman Tom Wheeler, Commissioner Jessica Rosenworcel and Commissioner Michael O'Rielly (Source: FCC)

According to Washington insiders, the Title II cause appeared doomed after big tech companies like Google and Facebook decided to sit out the fight. While Yahoo last week made a slight peep[20] that Title II might be necessary to prevent discrimination, the rest of the Silicon Valley giants — apart from Netflix — have stayed mum. While the tech industry would have likely lost a lobbying battle to Comcast even if it had opened its check book, its absence from the fight all but guarantees the FCC will leave Title II on the shelf.
Not everyone is pessimistic, of course. Harold Feld, a VP at consumer interest group Public Knowledge, says that the level of public awareness this time is far higher than the last time the FCC debated net neutrality.
'A lot of this clever political analysis applies to the last war,' he said, noting that pundits have declared other FCC decisions to be foregone conclusions — and then been proved wrong.
Finally, there is the matter of Chairman Tom Wheeler, who holds the ultimate card in the Title II debate. He's a former cable lobbyist, and seemed a pushover, but has also shown a recent independent streak — and even warned that he 'won't hesitate to use Title II.'
If Wheeler is reading this, he may wish to ponder the example of the man who said 'speak softly and carry a big stick.' It was Teddy Roosevelt, who is the subject of another famous quote[21] by a powerful corporate baron, who complained of the President that: 'We bought the son of a bitch, and then he didn't stay bought.'

urn:contentItem:5T1C-SNP1-DXVP-V558-00000-00Title VII solution for social media censorship2018-08-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:37:22ZLexisNexisRAPID REACTIONSTitle VII solution for social media censorshipCheryl K. Chumley

All this social media censorship talk that's been fueling conservative angst in recent months has had the distressing effect of putting the ideological right exactly where the left wants it in a regulatory box with nowhere to go.

The solution? The ideological right needs to create a new battlefield. How about amending Title VII of the Civil Rights Act?

Look at the situation; look at what's going on.

You've got months and months of headlines and stories and statistics and analyses showing the censorship realities of being caught conservative on social media. Ask Diamond and Silk, the black pro-President Donald Trump duo who were shut out of Facebook for what they say were their political posts. Ask conservative talk show host Dennis Prager, who sued YouTube unsuccessfully for unfairly restricting access to Prager University videos. Ask Alex Jones who was just the target of a massive social media scrubbing by Facebook, by Google, by Apple.

That's but a partial list.

So what have conservatives done to fight this unfair censorship?

By and large, to call for government regulation against the big-tech companies.

No, no and triple no. Regulating the free market is a leftist's talking point, not a conservative one. Conservatives calling for crackdowns on social media companies plays right into the left's hands.

There's nothing the hard left serving the globalist gods would like more than to get a foot in the door of regulating content on the internet. First a foot then a fist.

"Leaked [George] Soros document calls for regulating Internet to favor 'Open Society' supporters," screamed one Daily Caller headline in August of 2016.

"Hacked documents reveal Soros plans for more Internet regulation," ran another from the Washington Examiner, a month later.

This is the plan.

"Documents obtained through the breach of George Soros' Open Society Foundations reveal a comprehensive vision for the future of the Internet, with the philanthropic group funding at least 13 organizations to promote expanding government-funded access and encouraging regulatory influence over the content users view," the Examiner piece stated.

This is the goal.

It's really rather ingenious how the left has managed to create a censorship system that has the ideological right calling for government regulation.

Ingenious and despicable.

"Infowars," Democratic Sen. Chris Murphy just tweeted, "is the tip of a giant iceberg of hate and lies that uses sites like Facebook and YouTube to tear our nation apart. These companies must do more than take down one website. The survival of our democracy depends on it."

But conservatives need to tread cautiously here.

Choices are limited it's not as if there's a Republican-led tech firm waiting to bust open the social media market and provide a welcoming mat for the conservatives of the world.

But here's a thought: What if instead of pressing for Congress to do something, the White House to do something, the regulators on Capitol Hill to do something what if instead of demanding the social media giants be treated like public utilities or as monopolies, and regulated accordingly what if conservatives took a different tack?

What if conservatives created a new battle ground that makes the left at least dance a little nervous dance?

Currently, Title VII of the Civil Rights Act prohibits employers from discriminating based on race, color, religion, sex and national origin.

Let's add a category called "political belief."

It's not the perfect solution, but it's a start. Yes, it's true, Title VII only guides employer-employee relations. And yes, it's true  amending the code to include political belief is not an overnight fix to all this censorship.

But creating this category would help keep censorship regulation away from government hands and more in the private market, and it would give those employees who've been harmed by censorship who've been discriminated against or treated unfairly at the workplace the tools to successfully fight the bias in court.

Companies don't like to pay punitive damages. They also don't like the negative publicity that goes along with fighting civil rights' infringements in court.

Adding "political belief" to Title VII would soon enough send the signal throughout the private market that discriminating against someone for the crime of being an elephant in a firm filled with donkeys is as serious an offense as discriminating against someone's skin color. It wouldn't take long for these same provisions to be extended to customers, consumers and clients of these social media companies. And why wouldn't they be? Culture changes can indeed start small but sweep a nation.

Title VII protections for political beliefs may not be the only solution to the social media censorship problem, or even the best one. But it's an idea worth considering, at least for the long-term and at least while floundering to find ways to control the bias without violating core conservative principles.

At the least it might keep conservatives from walking right into the lion's den of Democratic talking points, and giving away the internet to government regulators.

• Cheryl Chumley can be reached at cchumley@washingtontimes.com or on Twitter, @ckchumley.

urn:contentItem:5BR5-VDR1-JB20-G423-00000-00TiVo at Deutsche Bank Media, Internet and Telecom Conference - Final2014-03-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:37:22ZLexisNexis031014a5314786.786TiVo at Deutsche Bank Media, Internet and Telecom Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Tom Rogers

TiVo Inc.- President and CEO

Presentation

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Thanks, everyone for joining. I'm here with Tom Rogers, the President and CEO of TiVo. A little bit of a fireside chat here at the media, internet, and telecom conference. Thanks everyone for joining. And thank you, Tom, for joining us today. I think this is our second year in a row in this format.

TOM ROGERS, PRESIDENT AND CEO, TIVO INC.: Thank you for having us. There has never been a time I more looked forward to being in Palm Beach.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: I think a lot of us from the Northeast feel the same way. So, Tom, maybe if you could, we could kind of just dive in on your recent results and talk a little bit about the Company's performance and then maybe we'll get into a little bit more on where you see the marketplace going.

TOM ROGERS: Well, we announced our full-results last week and it was a great year. We had record net income, we had record service and technology revenues, our key revenue measure. We had record EBITDA, gross profit. Year-over-year we up over 1 million subs. For the fourth quarter, we had record revenues, record SMO sub growth of 313,000. So from a metrics point of view, a good year, a good quarter and I think when you look beyond the numbers to look at what did the year mean in terms of what TiVo is most know for which is innovation in the advanced television space, I think it was a banner year for us also in terms of maintaining leadership there.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Fantastic. And Tom, obviously you are getting pretty close to 10 years now at the helm. And when you think about the TV landscape, which there has been a lot of change and then looking at viewer habits and where things are going, how do you see --

TOM ROGERS: I said eight years. Don't advance me too quickly.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: I was eight years in the Marines. I tend to round off to 10 years sometimes myself, call it a decade.

How do you see things going forward for viewing in the home and for outside the home and how do you think TiVo will play into those strategies?

TOM ROGERS: Well, when I came to TiVo, the Company was really in a down and out position. Many didn't think we were going to survive. It looked like TiVo was known for having created the DVR but having been rejected soundly by the cable industry that had taken on a bunch of generic alternatives, we looked like we had been marginalized.

And the question was asked repeatedly, so what happens to TiVo. The question was are the patents worth anything? It doesn't look like you guys really have defensible intellectual property given how the world has created generic alternatives to your major innovation.

Then people said, the cable industry is never going to embrace TiVo as we began to focus on could we work with operators as a way to overcome the fact that they had initially rejected us? Look, they have rejected you, they have moved on, they have no role for you. The question was whether -- the Company will never be profitable, it is losing $100 million EBITDA a year, something to that effect, it is going to run out of cash. And you can't be a one trick pony in a constantly moving world of technological development. And you guys are going to quickly be surpassed by much bigger players who can innovate much faster than you can.

And we kind of one at a time knocked those off. We showed that the patents are valuable to the tune of almost $2 billion of patent wins, that certainly answered the question are we going to run out of cash. The issue of whether the cable industry will work with us, we said, look, we offer something when it comes to where the world is going, it goes way beyond the DVR because what the DVR really was about was giving people an easy way to access on-demand television. And with everything moving on demand most recently streaming video, how do you create a user experience that is all about giving people the access of what they want, when they want it? We were able to demonstrate that working with the cable industry was something we could do. And now 18 of the top 25 cable, satellite and phone operators in the United States are one way or another dependent on us for driving their user experience.

And when it came to profitability, we said, look, this year we will be probably north of $100 million of EBITDA. Certainly we think that is well within the realm of what we're capable of doing. And they answered that question.

And then the question is, are you a one trick pony? And look at the reviews for Roamio, our most recent retail product, and people think it has innovated and evolved in a way that is beyond anything else offered by way of an advanced television solution.

The big question now is, okay, you have got a lot of cash on your balance sheet and what you are going to do with it? And we have begun to answer that but in the scheme of the questions that have been hanging over our heads for the last eight years, that is an easier one than the other ones.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: So, on the cable side, you are obviously having tremendous success and your range of solutions on how you approach MSO customers is a little different with each. I think we have seen in some cases you're able to fully integrate with the video on demand product with some of the operators. And there is just a range of alternatives.

Can you talk a little bit about where you are with the MSOs and do you have a preferred way to play when you partner with them on their user experience?

TOM ROGERS: Well, I think one of the reasons that we have been partnered with by a number of MSOs is there are many different ways to play with TiVo. And I think we've shown that there is a high degree of flexibility there and there are guys who are still fully in the QAM-based technology world where we have got one set of answers, there are people that are transitioning that are highly QAM based on the set-top box front but want to implement IPTV to secondary screens and we've shown a way to do that. And there are others who are moving more quickly into a full IPTV implementation most recently with Com Hem, the largest cable operator in Scandinavia. We have shown the ability to do that.

And I think the preferred way for us to work with operators is to say, look, we've got a great user experience, and the UI elements on the screen are critical to the -- how we've traditionally shown people that menuing, navigating, discovering, searching, browsing through content, TiVo has a great way to do it. But there is the TiVo service, which powers the user experience, which is increasingly the fundamental elements that we built into the cloud and that relating to us through those elements is another way to think about what TiVo does. And that includes moving ultimately to an nDVR which we've demonstrated how our particular approach to that we think gives the cable operators some unique flexibility in the cloud space.

And so we have also been able to show that for operators that want a whole home solution, a multi screen solution, a solution that goes beyond the set-top itself, we have the flexibility to do that.

And the acquisition of Digitalsmiths, which was really a way for larger operators to think about it, they were going to focus on the user experience themselves and not take the full -- not take a TiVo type solution that was the full array of all those pieces how they could relate to a cloud-based service for that component.

And so now the flexibility has turned into yet one more way to relate to TiVo and I think the more we do for an operator the more we like it, the more we package in the UI as part of what we do, the more we think it gives the consumer the best of breed of everything. But certainly there are multiple ways to access working with us at this point.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: And for the consumers who purchase their hardware at retail and have a relationship directly with TiVo, having their video service provided by a third party, are you learning from those customers and where do you see the retail component going longer term? Is it something that will continue to grow and you will find ways to serve them in a different way?

TOM ROGERS: Well, that was another area where we had a great quarter. We were up 40% year-over-year in terms of retail subs. It was the first quarter in six years that we had net positive sub additions because that retail line, which had been churning heavily in terms of older TiVo units certainly for the first time seeing a net sub addition there was great. Lowest churn in absolute terms that we've seen in that line in eight years. So a lot of positive elements there.

We do believe based on the fact that we marketed in about a dozen markets Roamio in the fourth quarter more heavily than we did on a national basis, which was very limited money spent and we saw much higher than 40% year-over-year growth in those markets. That all gives us the sense that the metrics are pointing in the direction that people can understand the difference between TiVo and alternatives, they can be educated that no just because they have a DVR, it doesn't mean they have TiVo, that there are elements there that make it a winning proposition that can resonate.

We have a new CMO, which we announced today, a guy who ran marketing for both Dish and Sirius Satellite at different points who we think armed with the right product, the right fourth quarter testing and the knowhow he has can help drive that.

But what we learned from those subscribers is everything that you want to be as a consumer electronics company with cutting edge information and cutting edge DNA about what consumers want and what you need to know to satisfy them. And it relates heavily to how we to have won accounts on the cable side. because cable operators know, they know one thing, they know the traditional vendors in the cable space let them down, let them down badly. That it was principally driven by hardware box guys who did not see what the power of the cable industry was when it came to having channels and programming content that was more extensive than any other player out there and a broadband pipe that they had invested billions in to being the highest speed Internet connection that was tailor-made for high volumes of video getting to the home. And yet the notion of combining the video and broadband sides of their business into an advanced television experience that was commensurate with those attributes that they had, their vendors just let them down.

And TiVo came and created an opportunity for us and the fact that we were driven by a consumer electronics DNA that was much more attuned to what the consumer needed and where the market was going is something that has resonated with operators in a way most of our accounts are based on that.

Now the retail side of the equation, people said, well how can you have a retail business that competes with the operator? Well, it doesn't really compete with the operator. It is all based on cable card technology where you have to be a cable subscriber to get our box. And what we've shown is if somebody is a retail customer of TiVo, they churn less and watch more DoD and the characteristics of that sub look much better than a cable operator who wouldn't otherwise be offering TiVo.

So the fact of the matter is it looks like it helps us in the cable world.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: And are most of those retail customers that you are adding, are they doing a self installation or are the cable companies involved at all in helping put your equipment into a customer's home?

TOM ROGERS: It differs. Most are involved in a self installation. There is friction in the cable card world because the cable operator has to give you that cable card and some insist on showing up and needing a service call to do it even though they may only charge you a couple dollars for the cable card or some give it to you for free. And in those cases, they don't necessarily make it easy for self installation and that whole process could have less friction. And it is an unfortunate part of the retail setup that it isn't totally frictionless. But it has gotten better than it was and the FCC has had some regulations that have had some effect to make it better than it was.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: And, Tom, on multiroom functionality, what percentage of your new retail customers are taking on more than one piece of TiVo equipment and a new purchase? Are you tracking that at all?

TOM ROGERS: We do track that. We found I think close to 78% of those who have the capability were using it -- some streaming, roaming capability in the course of a month meaning they were connecting to some other piece of hardware beyond their television set for purposes of a television experience.

I was in my hotel room this morning and wanted to watch Morning Joe, my alma mater network of MSNBC, and took out my iPad and tapped into my bedroom TiVo and was sitting there with the ability to see my recordings in live television and that is not only getting more usage, the sessions are turning longer. I think unlike other alternatives for doing that where people are able to see something remotely but they hijack the tuner of the television set, so the person at home now is stuck watching what you have to watch remotely, our implementation of that with the number of tuners we have gives the ability for a kid at college, say, who has no ability to get cable in his dorm to have full access to their -- to his home cable television service and it totally doesn't disrupt the brothers and sisters at home from watching what they want to watch when they want to watch it.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: You don't just hijack the basement TV.

TOM ROGERS: Right, right. And it has become a -- I think one of those key features that has really resonated with consumers.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: That's fantastic. And you have come very far, very fast in these last few quarters. Where do you see new product innovation going for TiVo? And how do you continue to deliver value other than executing and growing your sub base, where are the new points of value for TiVo likely to come from?

TOM ROGERS: Well, it is a world of constantly evolving content and the promise with TiVo is get everything you want when any of you want it. So integrating more and more content. But then three key themes. One is continued mobility; there is no doubt that more ways for people to watch where they want, when they want with features and elements that make the mobile experience even easier is one key area.

Two is clearly ongoing IPTV and cloud-based implementation. That is important in a lot of respects but most importantly for the cable operator to get out from under the CapEx burdens of their current environment and be able to have as much reliance on the cloud as possible, cheaper CapEx in the home and I think the TiVo service has already proved that it is a real embodiment of that whole theory of the case and our nDVR implementation I think has characteristics that make the management of content for the cable operator equivalent to the ease and simplicity that we provided for content management for the consumer. And so there is more to come on that front, where there is R&D going.

And thirdly really importantly, is personalization. What we see over and over again is the thing that consumers most value is speed to content. Connect me to what I most care about as quickly as you can and don't put me into a world of infinite choice with no ability to really get at what is relevant to me when I turn on the television set. And having the ability to filter for what you have watched in the past, what you have recorded, what your friends and family recommend to you, what key reviewers or people in the press you follow by way of recommendations, what is popular and buzzy in the genres you most care about, be able to filter that and immediately any time somebody comes to the television, have the kind of relevance available that gives them immediate access to the choices that would filter to the top.

We have done some of that already, we have more of that to come this year. And I think really the underpinnings of TiVo in terms of what makes us successful is more and more about how many -- how much data we can process to constantly improve the product.

There is the Digitalsmiths is a great example of that vast amount of content metadata that we ingest to be able to power the user experience. This personalization data which gets to the individual users predilections for what matters and be able to constantly process and spit that back out. And then thirdly, audience research analytics and the value for advertisers as to what or how that can be relevant to their decisions. And the amount of metadata that are key anchors of the TiVo product when you take all three of those buckets and combined them is really quite extraordinary.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: So there's a lot of elements to the personalization then, right, from getting to the content that matters most in as quick a fashion as possible, having commercials that are relevant, searching for new shows and recommendations I would assume would be an important part of that. And it seems like things like a tablet are a much more personal TV experience than their family TV on the wall.

TOM ROGERS: I think a lot of the innovation starts with the tablet. You can get it out faster, but what distinguishes us in many respects is how complicated getting it to the set-top box is and the ability, for instance, what is on now, which is what to watch now, which is a key feature on TiVo that takes your favorite channels and tells you movies, sports, other things that are hugely relevant and gets to know which sports teams you care most about and tells you immediately if it is a close game or something and what to go in for.

And that started on the tablet. We brought it to the TV six months later. And so the set-top box continuing to be -- gives you the main screen experience is something that we consider vital to what we do, but you are right, you can more quickly bring these things to the fore with an iPad.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: And are people using more and more their iPads and their iPhones as a remote control and how they are interacting with the TV and bypassing the traditional mode or is TiVo traditional remote still a really important product?

TOM ROGERS: I mean, we have that capability, for a remote control on the phone and I think over time that will increasingly become a way people do it. Right now we are just seeing -- it is amazing but in the cable world if you don't have TiVo, there is no way to move a recording which are the things by definition people care most about because most people don't watch, particularly their favorite entertainment as opposed to sports except on a recorded basis.

And the most -- if you are a cable subscriber and you want to move that stuff to an iPad, you can't do it, you can't move a recording unless you have TiVo. And we are finding the viewing consumption resonating much more than anything else. Remote control is kind of sure, if I have my phone available, I don't need to know where my remote is. But one of the things about TiVo that is unique is people are always misplacing the remote, it is under a couch cushion or something. We have a little button on the TiVo you can push and it sounds the remote so you can find it easier. So that is important but less valued.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: And then bringing it back to financial results. And you are obviously creating more net income, more free cash flow. Where do you see that in evolving over the next few years and maybe then we can talk a little bit about the research and development and where the budget and capital goes on that side.

TOM ROGERS: Well, we really haven't projected out beyond saying that our expectation is we should be able to do $100 million of the EBITDA this year. But the elements that grow the model are clearly continued penetration of our existing MSO subscribers. We have about -- if you take away our deals with Comcast and DIRECTV, have about 10 million homes in the footprint of the MSOs today that use us as their primary advanced TV solution, we are about 30% penetrated there. But we have substantial upside.

Digitalsmiths, which has worked with operators that have a footprint of about 65 million homes and they are about 10% penetrated. We think they can get to 50% penetrated or more in the next few years so there is substantial upside there. And both of those are before new deals are brought on board where we have a very substantial pipeline.

So MSO growth generally coming from those sources we think is a substantial way to power it. We have seen what has in a declining revenue line in the retail business what we saw with the fourth-quarter growth I mentioned and up 40% in retail subs, some opportunity for beginning to look at that line again because of how distinctive the Roamio product is, it is a way to drive additional growth.

And then the advertising and analytics line of our business, which has been a minor area but one that the market as you can see from rent track stock is being highly valued even with revenue streams that are relatively nascent at this point, we believe that the contribution again core to us being metadata and the capturing of data and having software that uniquely is able to process that data, that that is going to be an increasingly valued component of our overall model and that one we think also has substantial upside.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: And to stay with that media measurement piece and look at the mobile environment, you mentioned using your TiVo from home in your hotel room. Obviously you watch certain programs and probably viewed certain advertisements that advertisers would like to know. Is that the kind of thing that you are measuring these days and is there as large an opportunity on sort of the mobile or portable side as there is in the home?

TOM ROGERS: Well, there is a number of pieces that advertisers want to know. First, they want to know that you've got a sample size that is really giving them a view, which is where Nielsen's sample was pretty constrained, 20,000 homes. And the more viewing options there are, the more fragmented it becomes, the more important the sample size becomes important.

Two is the whole cross media and multi-screen element; they don't want to just know what you are watching off the television, they also want a major sample size when it comes to the cross media element.

Third, they want to understand another point you made, which is on-demand television, if you are not watching a traditional channel but somehow it is an on-demand viewing experience, they want to know what that is. And within all of those what they really want to know is who saw the ad? Because there are different ways of measuring the programming. But we all know that programming and watching a commercial have really become separated in terms of how consumers go about it.

And one of the key things which really launched our whole analytics approach here is to show, hey, just because somebody has watched a recording doesn't mean they have watched the ad. We all know that is what you do is you fast-forward through the ads. And the thing about the television space is the most highly rated programs, the more highly rated you are as an entertainment show, the more likely you are you going to be recorded and the more likely your commercials are going to be avoided.

And measuring that since that is the most highly sought after advertising time, the fact that it also has the highest degree of commercial avoidance creates a real issue for the advertiser understanding who is seeing what. And then what we have added to that is it wasn't enough to know who saw what, you had to know what people would purchase based on what they saw or where the swing purchasers were showing up that you could most influence. And we have shown that the return on investment of your marketing dollar when guided by those kind of analytics are far more important than the traditional ways people have bought and sold advertising time, which is age and income demographics and sex demographics.

And that is I think going to continue to wane as a key means of evaluating media buying and purchasers swing purchasers, competitive purchasers is going to increasingly grow. But being able to show that on a cross media and on-demand basis is critical.

The kind of analytics we capture I think are going to be uniquely suited to serving that environment. The market hasn't moved there yet, it is going slower than we hoped. Certainly though the market is valuing set-top box data. As Rent Track showed, we think we begin to capture that when it begins to highly value these other forms of advanced analytics, which can really guide marketing decisions.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: And is the right way to think about this that the personalization and the user experience and the data that comes from -- or the services that are enabled by the excellent personalization, will tie in ultimately with the -- what the advertisers want to learn about consumer behavior and ad skipping versus --.

TOM ROGERS: Yes, it will and they already do. I mean when we capture this information today across several million homes, we know what somebody has watched on a second-by-second basis and then we know exactly what that same household bought. We aren't taking samples and equating, well, this is the characteristic so it is this kind of household and they may have bought these products. We know exactly the viewing and purchasing behavior coming out of that very home. As that begins to be increasingly personalized, the value of that information obviously increases. We are (inaudible) by the way so we know it is the same home. We don't know whose home it is.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Protect your customers' data. That is right. So, Tom, a question I'm sure you get all the time. But with all of the cash that TiVo has accumulated through the performance of the business and just accessing the litigation, what do you think about the cost of carrying that cash and is it something you view as enabling potential M&A, potential return of capital to shareholders, the balance, how do you explain that position to investors these days?

TOM ROGERS: We said we were going to be cautious and deliberate, and I think we have been. And I think we will continue to be. If I had taken a survey of analysts and said what are the companies we should consider buying, I think I would've gotten a dozen responses and none of them would have been Digitalsmiths. And we looked at a number of companies, turned things inside out and came away with a decision that in terms of a first major purchase, which was only about 10% of our cash on the issue of putting us in business with major operators who weren't in business yet, in terms of something that was accretive but also had substantial long-term growth characteristics, had a software as a service model with the kind of margins that flow from it and was completely strategically consistent with going to the cloud and a TiVo service type offering, it met a lot of characteristics that we said make this a winning M&A opportunity.

But it was a very cautious and deliberate approach to assessing that. And I think we will continue to do that. Some people get quite ideological about this, you ought to return all of your money to shareholders or, you know what, you guys should not be doing M&A unless there is something truly transformative out there that you should buy and invest and be done with it but make your decision and move on.

And we have had over $1 billion on our balance sheet really only the last seven, eight months and our view was look, we will return money to shareholders as we have had. We have announced we have increased our authorization to $300 million. We indicated earnings, we were going to execute another $100 million of buy back on top of what we have already done, which has been over $100 million. And I think we have shown a balanced deliberate approach that has been cautious but both which both passed very much geared toward increasing shareholder value in a way that I think the cash is a real strategic asset for us.

TOM ROGERS: On relationships that you would like to have maybe with technology vendors or others, are there any out there that you are thinking about from a category perspective where you are obviously building great relationship with the MSOs on the sort of the big tech players. Are there anybody out there that you think is interesting that could help TiVo grow to the next level?

TOM ROGERS: Well, we certainly are constantly evaluating that. We play with a lot of other technology companies and first and foremost when it comes to technology is our own R&D. We have substantial R&D investment. I think one of the interesting things about what we've accomplished in the last year or so is we have never innovated more, we have never done more R&D projects or more implementations for operators yet we've been able to take our R&D down, took it down about 7% last year. We are going to continue to reduce our R&D this year.

And I think the fact that we can look at a more efficient R&D line with more and more innovation coming out of the pipeline at the same time is a pretty good statement of our feeling that we can handle our technology needs but obviously if there's something out there that we think does it more cheaply or can accelerate our growth and minimize our internal investment, we will take a hard look at it.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: And on the R&D side, as you have provided solutions to different carriers they probably become applicable to other carriers. So your toolkit probably grows. How far do you think you've pushed the envelope there on the solutions that TiVo has today relative to your R&D budget? And is the continued ability to scale back and generate more free cash flow and grow the products you have maybe likely for the foreseeable future?

TOM ROGERS: I think on the domestic US front our efficiencies relative to what we -- the scale of innovation that we bring to an operator has been really phenomenal. We now can get from deal to implementation with an operator in about four months and a $300,000 investment or so. And it is -- when you think -- when an operator sees how quickly we can move the -- I'm not talking about the recurring sub fees -- but just the cost of getting them up and going and ability to roll and the vastness of the change that it means in terms of the technology available to other subscribers, that is a really efficient play.

And we haven't been able to get to that same level of efficiency internationally, technologies aren't just homogeneous, many different vendor combinations, many different stages of DVR rollout, development and all that makes the customization in those implementations far more R&D and [RE] heavy. But I am hopeful that with the increasing amount moving to the cloud and with that bringing a certain amount of homogeneity to the implementation that we will begin to see some efficiencies on that front as well.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Perfect. Thank you for dividing that between the US and International, that is helpful. I think we have time for a couple of questions if anybody in the audience had anything they wanted to ask Tom while we are together. Okay.

Well Tom, we talked about a lot of things about TiVo and maybe in closing before closing remarks, maybe you can talk a little bit about the risks in the business and how you see them being mitigated and then whatever you would like to share as we close the session.

TOM ROGERS: Well, I guess the risks are -- relate most to MSO deployment of what we do. One is certainly the pace of decision-making. That has probably been our biggest frustration. We have moved the marketplace substantially, have won more advanced television accounts than anybody else, but we would have hoped that by now given how operators need to do this with over-the-top cord cutting, other technology threats, that internationally particularly we would have seen a faster pace of making the decisions to get this stuff going to get to market. And so that is a risk, how quickly those decisions are made.

Certainly another risk is players out there that don't have anywhere near the quality of software solution we have but may have a huge balance sheet even by its standards of what we have on our balance sheet and are able to subsidize hardware decisions even though they have far less robust software capability. Cisco comes to mind. Operators who have to make massive CapEx investment relative to and make that trade off and say, I want to have best-of-breed software but somebody is just making it real attractive for me on the hardware front. You know, that kind of decision-making process is certainly a risk to us.

But a lot of the risks that people have pointed to for us over the last few years have kind of gone by the wayside and we see a much clearer path to our continued leadership in the MSO front. And that is a good thing but decision-making risks and those competitive risks certainly abound.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Good. We thank you very much for your time today, Tom, I think we are a little bit over. But it was a pleasure speaking with you.

TOM ROGERS: Thank you for having me, enjoy it, thank you very much.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Thanks for coming.

The Treaty between Mexico, the United States and Canada (T-MEC) strengthens the protection of industrial secrets with penalties that reach the prison, benefiting the world's ever-expanding major technology companies.

According to the T-MEC, in civil, criminal and regulatory proceedings in which industrial secrets may be brought before a court or governing entity, each Party shall prohibit unauthorized disclosure of an industrial secret by an official at the central level of government, outside the scope of that person's official functions.



Each Party shall establish in its legal system deterrent sanctions, including fines, suspension or termination of employment, and imprisonment to prevent unauthorized disclosure of an industrial secret.

A recent report by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNTAD) highlights that the participation of multinational technology and digital companies in total overseas sales of the 100 major multinationals globally increased during the period 2017 to 2019, from less than 17% to more than 18%.

In the same period, its share of foreign assets increased from 10% to 11% (it proves the light nature of the assets of its overseas operations).

T-MEC and multinationals

The trend towards a stronger role for technology and digital companies in the Top 100 continues. They included five emerging market companies: Hon Hai (Chinese Province of Taiwan), Samsung (Republic of Korea), Tencent (China), Huawei (China) and Legend Holding (China).

Chapter 20 of the T-MEC has great relevance to the United States, where many of the world's leading technology companies are located, applying stricter standards in copyright, trademark, patent, and industrial secret protection.

In civil, criminal and regulatory proceedings in which industrial secrets may be brought before a court or government entity, each Party shall prohibit unauthorized disclosure of an industrial secret by an official at the central level of government, outside the scope of that person's official functions.

Each Party, provided for by the T-MEC, shall establish in its legal system deterrent sanctions, including fines, suspension or termination of employment, and imprisonment to prevent unauthorized disclosure of an industrial secret.

Industrial secret means information that:

A trade secret is information that you don't want to know the competition. Through industrial secrecy, much more information can be protected than can be protected with patents, which can only be granted to truly new technical innovations.

According to the T-MEC, secrecy encompasses any information that provides an advantage, even if someone is already using it; the only limitation is that it is not general knowledge.

urn:contentItem:5S76-TKV1-JBCN-40BV-00000-00T-Mobile and Sprint want you to be scared of China. Fear for yourself instead.2018-04-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:37:21ZLexisNexisTECHT-Mobile and Sprint want you to be scared of China. Fear for yourself instead.Pete Pachal

Fear is never the best foundation for a relationship, but it's exactly what T-Mobile and Sprint are counting on to fuel support for their proposed mega-merger. The deal would combine the two companies into a $146 billion behemoth better poised to compete with market leaders Verizon and AT&T.

But while T-Mobile and Sprint certainly want everyone to feel good about wireless competition, what they're really trying to stoke is fear of China.

The country isn't named in the official announcement, which is full of predictable talk of job creation, "synergies," and scale, scale, scale. You can tell a lot from a document's first line, though, and in this case Sprint and T-Mobile chose to emphasize that the merged company would have the network capacity to deploy 5G technology with a "breadth and depth critical to extend U.S. global internet leadership."

It only takes an elementary reading between the lines to know they're talking about China. A recent study by CTIA, a U.S.-based wireless association, found that China had a narrow lead in the race to deploy 5G, followed by South Korea in second place. Third place? That would be the good ol' U.S.A.

Getting scared yet? All the wireless carriers — not just T-Mobile and Sprint — hope you are, because if there's broad support to "beat" China to 5G, there will be more investment and government funding to create their networks.

Ultimately, the 5G race is really a matter of months: Both the U.S. and China have already started to develop these networks. But theoretically, whichever country deploys it first will have the most say in the direction it takes.

The problem is, by focusing on these macroeconomic issues, there's a greater chance regulators and stakeholders will overlook the person they should be keeping top of mind: the consumer.

The new Red Menace

This is starting to become an uncomfortable theme in tech these days: The growing call to demonize China and its tech companies with exaggerated fears, then exploiting those fears to push for policy that is fundamentally anticompetitive. Before T-Mobile and Sprint's 5G scare, AT&T responded to government pressure by scuttling a deal to sell phones from Huawei, China's top smartphone manufacturer.

The U.S. has decided to build its own Great Firewall, with economics instead of tech

That means, if you live in America, you can't buy the Huawei P20, one of the most innovative phones on the market today thanks to its three-camera system. It also means that not many U.S. companies will be using Huawei network equipment while they deploy 5G, even though there's no evidence to support claims of spyware in their phones or equipment. Huawei USA even employs as its head of cybersecurity a former director for the U.S. Department of Homeland Security.

Mark Zuckerberg was even ready to peddle the anti-China narrative when he testified before Congress. (His notes revealed that one possible defense against breaking up Facebook is the notion that it would strengthen Chinese internet companies.)

In the case of T-Mobile-Sprint, the China factor is a question on emphasis. Of course, the two companies claim customers will enjoy "unmatched value" when they merge, but consumer choice is clearly a secondary question. You only need watch T-Mobile CEO John Legere in this interview with Cheddar to get the real message.

.@JohnLegere says the T-Mobile and Sprint merger is necessary because only by combining the two companies will they have the resources to build out a broad 5G network in the U.S. #CheddarLIVE pic.twitter.com/BvJ2viPte0

— Cheddar (@cheddar) April 30, 2018

Here's the key quote from Legere (emphasis added):

Why now? Why will this get approved? One is the criticality of 5G for the United States and the innovation cycle that's underway that we currently as a nation are behind on.... This is very important policy-wise for the country.

Translation: Customers? Yeah, they'll be fine, but who cares? We gotta beat China to 5G!

Don't get me wrong here. China is no U.S. ally, and its track record on human rights is atrocious. State-mandated censorship has resulted in the Great Firewall, with Google and Facebook being banned. And the country is now wielding the incredible power of facial recognition and big data with the zeal of a Black Mirror writer — beefing up mass surveillance and assigning every citizen a "social credit score," with real consequences if it creeps too low. The gap in values between China and the West is vast.

But we can acknowledge China's problems and also be honest about what's really behind Big Tech's newfound concerns about them. This is economic protectionism, essentially a buy-in to a worldview also used as justification for the Trump administration's declared trade war with China, and the controversial tariffs that go along with it.

Who's afraid of fair competition?

To be fair, it's true that China has invested heavily in tech in recent years. It clearly wants to be No. 1 in 5G, and the strong link between wireless carriers and the government means it can move quickly on that plan. Chinese internet giants Tencent and Alibaba are two of the most valuable companies in the world. And just last year China announced an ambitious $150 billion vision to become a world leader in artificial intelligence by 2030.

But the U.S. is no slouch either. Even absent a T-Mobile-Sprint merger, all the big networks have announced aggressive deployment of 5G, with some trials planned to start this year, and network rollouts coming in 2019. China's commitment to AI is impressive, but so are the investments from all the major tech companies: Google, Apple, Amazon, Facebook, and Microsoft. And as nice as the Huawei P20 is, the iPhone still owns the high-end smartphone market.

So why not drop the scare tactics, and just let the market decide who has the best approach? T-Mobile itself — once left for dead after a failed AT&T merger of 2011 — is ironically one of the best examples of how fair competition leads to better products and lower prices. But somehow the fear of a technologically influential China means consumer choice comes second.

That should give everyone pause, but especially the U.S., because it's fundamentally un-American. It used to be the West was confident enough in its own innovations and ideas that it would accept competition in open markets. Instead, we've decided to start building our own version of the Great Firewall, just with economics instead of tech. Maybe this protectionism will work, and in the arenas of 5G, smartphones, and AI, China will lose. But either way, consumers certainly will.

urn:contentItem:5CCX-YG21-JBSS-S0PN-00000-00T-Mobile is at a crossroads, so is the U.S. wireless industry2014-06-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:37:22ZLexisNexisT-Mobileis at a crossroads, so is the U.S. wireless industryBy James O'TooleNEW YORK (CNNMoney)

NEW YORK (CNNMoney) -- The future of the U.S. wireless industry may soon be in the hands of the Obama administration.

Sprint and T-Mobile, are close to finalizing a $32 billion merger proposal, according to reports this week. If approved by regulators, the deal would unite the nation's third- and fourth-largest carriers into a combined entity with subscriber numbers comparable to industry leaders AT&T and Verizon.

The rumored merger has generated skepticism from some industry observers who worry about the creation of another telecom behemoth. But both Sprint and T-Mobilehave been losing money consistently, and they argue that they need to combine to take on their larger competitors.

T-Mobilehas provided a strong argument for the virtues of competition in recent months. Since the beginning of last year, the company has been engaged in an aggressive marketing campaign dubbed its "uncarrier" strategy. The goal is to upend the mobile industry, and it's been doing that by eliminating contracts, dropping international roaming charges and offering to pay competitors' customers $650 to switch over.

The company is also investing heavily to upgrade its infrastructure and expand its high-speed 4G-LTE network.

Sprint, AT&T and Verizon have all cut prices in response to T-Mobile's campaign, and they have begun moving away from two-year contracts as well.

This is the scenario the Justice Department envisioned when it blocked AT&T from buying T-Mobileback in 2011, saying the deal "would eliminate the important price, quality, product variety, and innovation competition that an independent T-Mobilebrings to the marketplace."

So far, T-Mobile's efforts have paid off in the form of increased market share. The company said last month that it added a record 2.4 million subscribers in the first three months of this year, its fourth consecutive quarter with over 1 million total net additions.

But these efforts have come at the cost of narrowing margins and widening losses. T-Mobilefinished the first quarter with a loss of $151 million, up from $20 million in the last three months of 2013.

"They can't continue this forever because it will cost them too much money, so the question is what's next," said industry analyst Jeff Kagan.

Some analysts see the carrier's recent moves as an effort to boost its asking price in a potential acquisition. T-MobileCEO John Legere said last month that consolidation in the industry was "a matter of when and not if," and that his company could benefit from the additional scale and assets a merger would offer.

Masayoshi Son, CEO of Sprint parent SoftBank, calls the U.S. wireless industry a duopoly, and says sustainable competition will emerge only with a third strong competitor.

Sprint and T-Mobiledid not respond to requests for comment.

The merger proposal has yet to be officially announced, but antitrust officials already have a lot on their plates.

AT&T announced last month that it hopes to buy America's biggest satellite television provider, DirecTV, in a deal worth almost $50 billion. Comcast, meanwhile, is trying to acquire Time Warner Cable, a $45 billion deal that would create the country's dominant provider of television channels and Internet connections.

"So much is in flux," Kagan said. "The industry is changing, and regulators now have to look at it from a new perspective."

Akshay Sharma, an analyst with Gartner, said the Justice Department would likely look more favorably on Sprint's bid for T-Mobilethan AT&T's failed effort from a few years ago, given Sprint's smaller size.

Should the deal fall through, T-Mobilecould prove an attractive acquisition target for another big tech company like DISH Network or an overseas carrier. What's clear is that neither T-Mobilenor Sprint can afford to maintain the status quo too much longer.

"It's innovate or die," Sharma said. "They just can't sit idle."

urn:contentItem:5CCX-YGP1-DY60-K04B-00000-00T-Mobile is at a crossroads, so is the U.S. wireless industry2014-06-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:37:22ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYT-Mobileis at a crossroads, so is the U.S. wireless industryJames O'Toole

The future of the U.S. wireless industry may soon be in the hands of the Obama administration.

Sprint and T-Mobile, are close to finalizing a $32 billion merger proposal, according to reports this week. If approved by regulators, the deal would unite the nation's third- and fourth-largest carriers into a combined entity with subscriber numbers comparable to industry leaders AT&T and Verizon.

The rumored merger has generated skepticism from some industry observers who worry about the creation of another telecom behemoth. But both Sprint and T-Mobilehave been losing money consistently, and they argue that they need to combine to take on their larger competitors.

T-Mobilehas provided a strong argument for the virtues of competition in recent months. Since the beginning of last year, the company has been engaged in an aggressive marketing campaign dubbed its "uncarrier" strategy. The goal is to upend the mobile industry, and it's been doing that by eliminating contracts, dropping international roaming charges and offering to pay competitors' customers $650 to switch over.

The company is also investing heavily to upgrade its infrastructure and expand its high-speed 4G-LTE network.

Sprint, AT&T and Verizon have all cut prices in response to T-Mobile's campaign, and they have begun moving away from two-year contracts as well.

This is the scenario the Justice Department envisioned when it blocked AT&T from buying T-Mobileback in 2011, saying the deal "would eliminate the important price, quality, product variety, and innovation competition that an independent T?Mobile brings to the marketplace."

So far, T-Mobile's efforts have paid off in the form of increased market share. The company said last month that it added a record 2.4 million subscribers in the first three months of this year, its fourth consecutive quarter with over 1 million total net additions.

But these efforts have come at the cost of narrowing margins and widening losses. T-Mobilefinished the first quarter with a loss of $151 million, up from $20 million in the last three months of 2013.

"They can't continue this forever because it will cost them too much money, so the question is what's next," said industry analyst Jeff Kagan.

Some analysts see the carrier's recent moves as an effort to boost its asking price in a potential acquisition. T-MobileCEO John Legere said last month that consolidation in the industry was "a matter of when and not if," and that his company could benefit from the additional scale and assets a merger would offer.

Masayoshi Son, CEO of Sprint parent SoftBank, calls the U.S. wireless industry a duopoly, and says sustainable competition will emerge only with a third strong competitor.

Sprint and T-Mobiledid not respond to requests for comment.

The merger proposal has yet to be officially announced, but antitrust officials already have a lot on their plates.

AT&T announced last month that it hopes to buy America's biggest satellite television provider, DirecTV, in a deal worth almost $50 billion. Comcast, meanwhile, is trying to acquire Time Warner Cable, a $45 billion deal that would create the country's dominant provider of television channels and Internet connections.

"So much is in flux," Kagan said. "The industry is changing, and regulators now have to look at it from a new perspective."

Akshay Sharma, an analyst with Gartner, said the Justice Department would likely look more favorably on Sprint's bid for T-Mobilethan AT&T's failed effort from a few years ago, given Sprint's smaller size.

Should the deal fall through, T-Mobilecould prove an attractive acquisition target for another big tech company like DISH Network or an overseas carrier. What's clear is that neither T-Mobilenor Sprint can afford to maintain the status quo too much longer.

"It's innovate or die," Sharma said. "They just can't sit idle."

urn:contentItem:5WNF-H1D1-JCPJ-W32M-00000-00T-Mobile's Sprint deal is approved. What will happen to the Bellevue HQ?2019-07-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:37:22ZLexisNexisT-Mobile's Sprint deal is approved. What will happen to the Bellevue HQ?Ashley Stewart

T-Mobile's headquarters plans have been among the biggest uncertainties for the Seattle area in the Bellevue-based company's proposed Sprint tie-up.

Justice Department regulators approved the $26.5 billion deal last week. It's a major reversal for a company with a history of failed acquisitions, including previous takeover attempts from AT&T and Sprint.

"Not that long ago, we thought T-Mobile was going to get acquired and leave town," real estate developer and former Bellevue City Councilman Kevin Wallace said. "Now they are the acquirer and they've made a long-term commitment to their Bellevue headquarters. It's such a remarkable turnaround."

T-Mobile said the company doesn't have specifics to share about which teams will be located where, but has said that the company will operate two headquarters.

The company's recent real estate moves, however, suggest Bellevue will remain the center of gravity for the combined T-Mobile.

T-Mobile is working on a $160 million renovation of the company's corporate headquarters in the Factoria neighborhood and extended leases for the space through 2030. The company has also been the main driver of real estate demand along the Interstate 90 corridor and has inked major leases in the past year outside of its headquarters office.

"All of their real estate actions to date indicate T-Mobile is cementing its footprint in Bellevue," said Gary Guenther, a Kidder Mathews senior vice president and partner who tracks the Bellevue market. "They're putting a lot of time and money into renovation for recruiting and retention purposes."

The decision ends some of the uncertainty created by the merger discussions. Employees are less likely to make big life decisions such as buying a home or starting a family during such uncertainty, and they are more likely to lose focus or search for a new job elsewhere.

While the conclusion of the merger may help to relieve uncertainty for employees, Guenther said it's not likely to result in a significant wave of new Bellevue-based workers or homebuyers.

"Big tech firms coming into the area will have a much bigger impact on housing and affordability than the merger," he said. "Employees of T-Mobile might be happy to have this in the rearview mirror, but T-Mobile is already established. It may grow by increments, but the big wave we're going to be seeing on the Eastside will be from Amazon, Facebook and Google."

Amazon, Facebook and Google are expanding in cities all across the Eastside. Most recently, Amazon disclosed plans to build a 1 million-square-foot tower in Bellevue.

While there are concerns that the merger may lead to layoffs, Broderick Group Principal Grant Yerke said T-Mobile's expansion "relieves any anxiety that a merger will result in job cuts in our area."

The combined company hasn't disclosed how it will operate two separate headquarters. Sprint tried that once before and it didn't work out.

When Sprint acquired Nextel in 2004 for $35 billion, the companies planned dual headquarters. Nextel's campus in Reston, Virginia, became the combined company's executive headquarters while Sprint's campus in Overland Park, Kansas, served as its operations headquarters.

Less than three years later, the two headquarters merged. Former Sprint Nextel Corp. CEO Dan Hesse at the time said the dual headquarters hampered teamwork and the integration of the companies' culture, increased travel and real estate costs and "hurt our ability to execute well in the marketplace."

T-Mobile CEO John Legere once told a group of Sprint employees he'd rather live in Kansas City, but later walked back those comments.

"For me right now, it's to remove the fear by people in Kansas City that we have a gigantic campus in Bellevue that's about to be renovated, for 10 years, it's an incredible piece," he said. "And we've got to acknowledge that we've got something there that we need and that we want - and, by the way, is a place that people like to live, right? And that we can attract and retain employees, too."

T-Mobile in 2018 had 51,787 employees, including 7,807 in Washington state, and reported more than $43 billion in revenue. The company in November said it had increased its headcount inside the Factoria campus by more than 56 percent in the past five years to more than 6,200 employees, excluding retail employees. The company employs 8,100 people in the Puget Sound region, also excluding retail employees.

Guenther, the Kidder Mathews partner, said it's unlikely T-Mobile will move a significant amount of employees to Kansas.

"I don't know much about Overland Park, Kansas, but I can't imagine they have the talent they have, although it probably has an affordability advantage," he said. "T-Mobile's corporate real estate decisions feels like it's planning to continue to grow in this area."
